From Publishers WeeklyChristopher Boone, the autistic 15-year-old narrator of this revelatory novel, relaxes by groaning and doing math problems in his head, eats red-but not yellow or brown-foods and screams when he is touched. Strange as he may seem, other people are far more of a conundrum to him, for he lacks the intuitive "theory of mind" by which most of us sense what's going on in other people's heads. When his neighbor's poodle is killed and Christopher is falsely accused of the crime, he decides that he will take a page from Sherlock Holmes (one of his favorite characters) and track down the killer. As the mystery leads him to the secrets of his parents' broken marriage and then into an odyssey to find his place in the world, he must fall back on deductive logic to navigate the emotional complexities of a social world that remains a closed book to him. In the hands of first-time novelist Haddon, Christopher is a fascinating case study and, above all, a sympathetic boy: not closed off, as the stereotype would have it, but too open-overwhelmed by sensations, bereft of the filters through which normal people screen their surroundings. Christopher can only make sense of the chaos of stimuli by imposing arbitrary patterns ("4 yellow cars in a row made it a Black Day, which is a day when I don't speak to anyone and sit on my own reading books and don't eat my lunch and Take No Risks"). His literal-minded observations make for a kind of poetic sensibility and a poignant evocation of character. Though Christopher insists, "This will not be a funny book. I cannot tell jokes because I do not understand them," the novel brims with touching, ironic humor. I read this about 2 1/2 years ago and wrote some interesting thoughts down that make up this review.The book is a nice play on the detective story. It’s told from the point of view of a severely autistic uncomprehending 15-year-old, and the POV is brilliant, it makes the book. He decides to solve a neighborhood mystery, using the lessons of Sherlocke Holmes in The Hound of the Baskervilles. He narrates, and we see everything only through his eyes, a stilted autistic lens where power of observation is in the details while the big picture is a gaping hole. So, essentially the whole atmosphere becomes a mystery which we struggle to understand; the details are our only clues. The narrator’s autism also sets an interesting tone. He uses language that barely betrays any emotion. But the emotion is there. It’s a fascinating commentary on autism, on how intelligent and reasonable this boy is, and yet a train ride to London is a life threatening, harrowing adventure. And on how his relationships are so painfully difficult. No touching, no appreciation of what we might consider truly great things, because it’s all too complicated and miserable. Instead, his pleasure comes only from routine and predictable things. When things make sense, and are calm, the calmness itself is pleasurable. On the flip side this POV is maybe the most authentically non-judgmental objective point of view there is. This boy is the perfect vehicle for a dry, detached social commentary. Through him, the world is what it is, and the rest is totally up to the reader’s opinions.

The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-time is a first-hand look on the world through autistic eyes; a bold, honest look at ourselves without the emotional fog that often blocks our view. Christopher had it tough, he was labeled right away as having Autism and immediately shoved under the 'disabled' category. Rather than embracing his gifts, society shunned him. Being treated the way he was made him look at everyone else in society in an experimental sort of way. He saw people as subjects of his own personal study of ‘normal’ human behavior. Since Christopher was told he was special, it made him wonder what was normal. What surprised me about this book was the fact that Christopher was labeled as someone who didn’t understand emotion at all and couldn’t handle social situations, yet since he was so smart was able to learn what emotions he was supposed to feel. Our society is very quick to judge, we don’t give people a chance to change and like to find the easiest solution to everything. While perhaps Christopher didn’t completely understand how to use emotions correctly all the time This novel shows very clearly how Christopher lived every day and how his life differs from ours. Also, through his eyes we see problems with our own society which is ironic in a way because in our society most people would see someone like Christopher as the one with the problem. I appreciate how the author flips that around and leaves us defenseless against the truth of our own actions. Christopher, even though he is a fictional character, has helped teach a lot of people many important lessons about how we need to sometimes take a step back and observe what is around us, take it all in, and apply it to how we act on a daily basis. This would be a great book to recommend to anyone who would love to learn about the world in a whole new way, from fresh eyes, eyes maybe they didn’t even know existed. This is a great novel to introduce people to Autism and mental disorders in general; Mark Haddon does a wonderful job of putting himself in an autistic child’s shoes.

When this book first came out, I dismissed it as a gimmicky work that would never stand the test of time. After weeks and weeks on the best seller lists, however, I finally decided to see what was making this little red title fly off the shelves. The book requires you to get past the somewhat implausible concept of a teenage autistic narrator named Christopher who writes with the simple precision of Hemingway. Once you swallow the concept (and you will), this odd narrator leads you through a moving detective story in which he uncovers some troubling family secrets while investigating the mysterious death of his neighbor's dog. This same story, told by an ordinary narrator, would be unremarkable. But using his love of math as a way of parsing through life's ambiguities and anchoring himself in a chaotic world, Christopher alternately wows you with his insights into how mathematical laws explain complex subjects like human evolution and then breaks your heart with his inability to complete everyday tasks like boarding a train. In the end, though, you may begin to question who is more balanced, the multitudes who carry on their lives without questioning what it's all about or this young autistic man who takes nothing for granted and lives true to his own logic-based code. -Kevin Joseph, author of "The Champion Maker"

"The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time" is typical current book-club fare. The "novel" s to betries hard to be clever and different, however, it is a light-weight approach that rests on a single concept alone - much like the other books "customers who also bought this book bought" do, such as "The Time-Traveler's Wife" and "The Secret Life of Bees". This particular story attempts to portray the mind of a 15-year old boy with Asperger's syndrome (a type of autism) amidst a canine murder mystery. Ok, so the premise is interesting; however, the narrative quickly becomes too polished and "gimmicky" - polished in the sense that we soon become overly familiar and comfortable with the writing, and all the diagrams, lists, puzzles and other attempted corky interludes (such as an appendix with a complicated mathematical proof") soon just become tiresome gimmicks. It doesn't help that the main character is given most of the "stereotypical" autistic traits as often seen in movies such as Rainman. The murder mystery is "solved" half-way trough in a rather predictable manner and is simply the catalyst for a family mystery involving the parents. Thrown in at the second part of the book is an adventure story involving a trip, a chase and some family friction before the neatly tied-up ending that includes family harmony and a fluffy puppy...awwww... The only aspect I found mildly interesting were the conflicting notions of logic and superstition in the narrator's mind. He quickly and matter-of-factly discards any religious ponderings and is quite comfortable with his logic-induced atheism; however, his illogical superstitions regarding everything from "bad" colors to predicting a day's outcome based on the procession of cars he sees from the schoolbus are indeed quite amusing. Simplistic - yes, but at least there is some sense of conflict that doesn't come across as utterly contrived. All in all, it is a quick read; however, the impact doesn't linger much longer after the book club discussion is over... PS: the narrative is littered with various factual-sounding tidbits to show the boy's extreme capacity to memorize trivia, but a bit of caution is in order - the author (or editor) should have made sure these facts are indeed correct...for instance, the Vikings did not roam about 2000 years ago! The mathematical savant is off by a 1000 years...

"Let's rustle up some tucker.""And now if I don't know what someone is saying I ask them what they mean . . ." This is a murder mystery. Most murder mysteries answer 2 questions: 1) Who did it? 2) Why did they do it? While those answers are often interesting, I'm not a big fan of the genre because the murderer never turns out to be the reader of the book. In real life, justice and the more enabling solutions are not found in simply finding someone else to blame, understanding their reasons for being destructive, and punishing them. It's more interesting to discover reasons to become more creative. This book is a well-motivated creative act. It is about the murder of a dog, which is unusual according to the narrator's therapist Siobhan "because readers cared more about people than dogs." But the narrator, a 15 yr old boy named Christopher, counters "I wanted to write about something real . . . and I cared about dogs because they were faithful and honest, and some dogs were cleverer and more interesting than some people." Christopher's father, Ed, warns him to "Keep your nose out of other people's business" and to not investigate who killed the dog. "It's a bloody dog, Christopher, a bloody dog." Christopher replies, "I think dogs are important, too." His father shouted, "I said leave it, for God's sake." But Christopher chooses not to leave it alone because it made him feel "happy, because I was being a detective and finding things out." Ed goes further, demanding that Christopher not mention Mr. Shears' name, not talk to Mrs. Shears, and not to ask anyone who killed that bloody dog. At first we don't know if Ed's moves to isolate and silence Christopher are protective. Only later do we find out his threats are primarily motivated by pride. The dog was an able comfort and support for Mrs. Shears. Sometimes Cain kills Able for his own proud reasons. And when Ed doesn't kill his perceived adversary, he cuts off communication (intercepting and prohibiting the exchange of letters) between two people who care about each other. This book is also about mathematics, basic cognitive building blocks, and prime numbers. Some people think this book is designed to give an autistic or Asperger's Syndrome perspective, but it is more universal than just that. The book is about trying to define basic things. Prime numbers are a symbol of basic, indivisible truths. As Christopher finds out, even prime numbers can be broken down, and sometimes answers to mysteries can be found in smaller fractions or more complex configurations. Christopher lays out his reasoning in simple diagrams, math equations, multiple choice options, and prose reasoning. He wants people to see his reasoning and judge it for themselves. He lacks inhibitions that would hide such things. We see where he makes reasoning errors. We see where he fails to grasp more options than he understands. One of my hopes in reading any new book is that the new ideas will cause me to go back and amend all my previous book reviews (you can do that here on Amazon). I walk away from this book being far more critical of the adults' behaviors relationship choices than Christopher's. The adults try to use overly simple equations to solve real, complex problems and they end up being consistently angry, excluding, or violent. There is no solution in this novel until each of the 3 main characters forgive each other and find ways for all of them to be a part of each others' lives. It is a complex, inclusive solution. And the solution involves a dog - as so many good solutions do. "Father was standing in the corridor. He held up his right hand and spread his fingers out in a fan. I held up my left hand and spread my fingers out in a fan and we made our fingers and thumbs touch each other. We do this because sometimes Father wants to give me a hug, but I do not like hugging people, so we do this instead, and it means that he loves me."

Amazon.comMark Haddon's bitterly funny debut novel, The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time, is a murder mystery of sorts--one told by an autistic version of Adrian Mole. Fifteen-year-old Christopher John Francis Boone is mathematically gifted and socially hopeless, raised in a working-class home by parents who can barely cope with their child's quirks. He takes everything that he sees (or is told) at face value, and is unable to sort out the strange behavior of his elders and peers.Late one night, Christopher comes across his neighbor's poodle, Wellington, impaled on a garden fork. Wellington's owner finds him cradling her dead dog in his arms, and has him arrested. After spending a night in jail, Christopher resolves--against the objection of his father and neighbors--to discover just who has murdered Wellington. He is encouraged by Siobhan, a social worker at his school, to write a book about his investigations, and the result--quirkily illustrated, with each chapter given its own prime number--is The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time.Haddon's novel is a startling performance. This is the sort of book that could turn condescending, or exploitative, or overly sentimental, or grossly tasteless very easily, but Haddon navigates those dangers with a sureness of touch that is extremely rare among first-time novelists. The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time is original, clever, and genuinely moving: this one is a must-read. --Jack Illingworth, Amazon.ca From Publishers WeeklyChristopher Boone, the autistic 15-year-old narrator of this revelatory novel, relaxes by groaning and doing math problems in his head, eats red-but not yellow or brown-foods and screams when he is touched. Strange as he may seem, other people are far more of a conundrum to him, for he lacks the intuitive "theory of mind" by which most of us sense what's going on in other people's heads. When his neighbor's poodle is killed and Christopher is falsely accused of the crime, he decides that he will take a page from Sherlock Holmes (one of his favorite characters) and track down the killer. As the mystery leads him to the secrets of his parents' broken marriage and then into an odyssey to find his place in the world, he must fall back on deductive logic to navigate the emotional complexities of a social world that remains a closed book to him. In the hands of first-time novelist Haddon, Christopher is a fascinating case study and, above all, a sympathetic boy: not closed off, as the stereotype would have it, but too open-overwhelmed by sensations, bereft of the filters through which normal people screen their surroundings. Christopher can only make sense of the chaos of stimuli by imposing arbitrary patterns ("4 yellow cars in a row made it a Black Day, which is a day when I don't speak to anyone and sit on my own reading books and don't eat my lunch and Take No Risks"). His literal-minded observations make for a kind of poetic sensibility and a poignant evocation of character. Though Christopher insists, "This will not be a funny book. I cannot tell jokes because I do not understand them," the novel brims with touching, ironic humor. The result is an eye-opening work in a unique and compelling literary voice.

I felt sympathetic towards his father and also admired him for giving so much to his son and knowing he will never get the usual signs of love that any parent expects and needs from their child. At the same time, christopher makes no apologies for not being able to show affection towards his parents, simply because he does not realize or understand it.

A 15-year-old boy, suffering from autism, one night encounters a dead dog on the front garden of one of his neightbours' house. He wants to find who did it. And so he goes "doing [his] detective work" and trying to solve the problem. Meanwhile, we get to know his life, his feelings, fears and thoughts. We really get into his brain. Due time (and consequence) he finds out that his mother is alive and lives far away. But he also finds the murderer of the dog -his father. So...he has some difficult decision to take: to stay with his father...or to go live with mom, somewhere, he doesn't even know where...Genre: Fiction.Setting: EnglandTime: 21 century.

Christopher goes to a special school, but he is not stupid. He knows all the capitals of all the countries, and all the prime numbers up to 7,057. He may be a mathematical genius and wants to be a scientist when he grows up. But he doesn't interact with people, can't stand being touched, and hates the color yellow. He lives with his dad. And he is determined to solve the mystery of who murdered his neighbor's dog.

Totally unique; totally readable. It seems like a light story told in a light tone; only when you stop to think about it do you realize how heavy the story is, and how unique it is to see things from Christopher's perspective. I know next to nothing about autism, but I found Christopher to be almost instantly relatable as a narrator - I liked that he was fairly self-aware about his thought processes, but that it wasn't a big melodramatic hand-wringing issue for him - it was just the way he was. Very refreshing, subtly funny in spots, heart-wrenching in others; a quick, light (but not really) read.

Christopher Boone is the autistic protagonist of this book. Christopher likes routine, mathematics, dogs, and Sherlock Holmes novels. When his neighbor’s dog is murdered, and he is incorrectly suspected as the killer, he decides to find out who did it, Sherlock-style, in both solving the mystery and writing it down. This reflexive style is fascinating- I love Christopher’s perspective on not understanding facial expressions, idiomatic expressions like “raining cats and dogs,” and the way he spends idle time by solving math problems in his head, and actually including said problems in the text. The book even has an appendix to show how he solved a particularly difficult question from an academic test he takes. Christopher also deviates from the story line sometimes, usually in order to make an extended metaphor, and gives you interesting scientific or historical tidbits that were also fun to read. This book is great. I loved it.

Haddon manages to tell the entire story through a stream-of-consciousness type voice, that of Christopher, a 15-year-old Austistic boy, without ever making it feel like a gimmick. Christopher has found his neighbor's dog murdered, and he sets out in the tradition of his favorite detective, Sherlock Holmes, to not only find who did it but to write a book about it. The story is not about the dog, though Christopher believes it to be, but mostly about Christopher and the things that happen around him, and the ways in which the world reacts to him and him to the world. It's fascinating, because the most interesting parts of the book happen in the background, and Haddon chooses -- wisely, in my opinion -- to stick to the voice he's created, to stick to the rules of Christopher's world, and thus to leave the readers without complete answers to every mystery. Nicely illustrated. I very much enjoyed this book.

Fifteen-year-old Christopher Boone can name all the prime numbers up to 2000, can tell there are 60 circles on his teacher's shoes, can figure out it takes exactly 21 minutes to take the bus to school. Christopher has an inquisitive mind, keenness to numbers, unusual intuition of space, but he doesn't like anything yellow or brown. Christopher has Asperger's Syndrome, a condition similar to autism. The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-time, unlike any book of fiction that I have read, deftly, but in very simplistic language that belongs to the voice of an autistic child, maps out Christopher's mind and emotions.When Christopher discovers that his neighbor's dog Wellington has been murdered with a garden fork, he skillfully applies his logical mind to probe the murder. Starting with neighbors on the same street, Christopher makes his inquiries but to no avail. His teacher Sihoban encourages him to keep all the clues that he has produced and discovered in a book which will eventually manifests into a book. When his father interferes at his investigation and locks up his journal, Christopher sets off a chain of events that unveil a shocking truth about his family. The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-time is after all a book about trust, integrity and reconciliation. It verbalizes the mind of an autistic child and internalizes his thinking, bringing his fear and insecurity to full actuality. The book shows great insight to the meticulously, pristinely set of routines that is built on logic and mathematical equations that governs the protagonist's life. The writing is compulsively simple and unadorned.
